It will be seen that, except where there is an irresistible suggestion conveyed by the surface meaning, that which is extracted from the Trumps Major by the divinatory art is at once artificial and arbitrary, as it seems to me, in the highest degree. But of one order are the mysteries of light and of another are those of fantasy. The allocation of a fortune-telling aspect to these cards is the story of a prolonged impertinence. The Pictorial Key to the Tarot, by A.E. Waite, ill. by Pamela Colman Smith [1911], at sacred-texts.com section 4 SOME ADDITIONAL MEANINGS OF THE LESSER ARCANA

10. The Wheel of Fortune. There is a current Manual of Cartomancy which has obtained a considerable vogue in England, and amidst a great scattermeal of curious things to no purpose has intersected a few serious subjects. In its last and largest edition it treats in one section of the Tarot; which--if I interpret the author rightly--it regards from beginning to end as the Wheel of Fortune, this expression being understood in my own sense. I have no objection to such an inclusive though conventional description; it obtains in all the worlds, and I wonder that it has not been adopted previously as the most appropriate name on the side of common fortune-telling. It is also the title of one of the Trumps Major--that indeed of our concern at the moment, as my sub-title shews. Of recent years this has suffered many fantastic presentations and one hypothetical reconstruction which is suggestive in its symbolism. The wheel has seven radii; in the eighteenth century the ascending and descending animals were really of nondescript character, one of them having a human head. At the summit was another monster with the body of an indeterminate beast, wings on shoulders and a crown on head. It carried two wands in its claws. These are replaced in the reconstruction by a Hermanubis rising with the wheel, a Sphinx couchant at the summit and a Typhon on the descending side. Here is another instance of an invention in support of a hypothesis; but if the latter be set aside the grouping is symbolically correct and can pass as such.

The Wheel of Life does not become visible until we step away from it. When we are involved in it we see only the events immediately before and behind us; the daily concerns our egos find so important. When we withdraw wx can see the whole pattern. Psychologically we can view this vision as an assessment a person makes of where his or her life has gone and where it is going. On a deeper level, the vision remains mysterious and symbolic. We can see what we have made of our particular lives, but fate remains a mystery. The symbols on the Wheel all possess meaning; they help us to understand the truth within the visions. Nevertheless, we do not experience the full living force. The light of the unconscious remains veiled. It is significant also that Malory connects the Wheel of Fortune to the Holy Grail. For the Grail symbols, which are also the symbols of the Minor Arcana, go back probably almost as far as the yearly regal sacrifice. When the candidate for initiation into the ancient European mysteries was given his ‘vision’ of the inner secrets of the cult it was most likely the four symbols of the cup, the sword, the lance, and the pentacle, that were shown to him with great mystic ceremony. And the basic tools of the ritual magic, laid on the Magician’s table, are the same four symbols and also the suits of the Minor Arcana. Though we do not see the four symbols directly on trump 10 we do see two of their many analogues. The four creatures on the corners of the card derive from the vision of Ezekiel 1:10. They appear also in Revelations 4:7. Now, over the centuries these four figures, sometimes called the ‘guardians of heaven’ came

The figure calls for no special description the face is rather dark, suggesting also courage, but somewhat lethargic in tendency. The bull's head should be noted as a recurrent symbol on the throne. The sign of this suit is represented throughout as engraved or blazoned with the pentagram, typifying the correspondence of the four elements in human nature and that by which they may be governed. In many old Tarot packs this suit stood for current coin, money, deniers. I have not invented the substitution of pentacles and I have no special cause to sustain in respect of the alternative. But the consensus of divinatory meanings is on the side of some change, because the cards do not happen to deal especially with questions of money. Divinatory Meanings: Valour, realizing intelligence, business and normal intellectual aptitude, sometimes mathematical gifts and attainments of this kind; success in these paths. Reversed: Vice, weakness, ugliness, perversity, corruption, peril. The Pictorial Key to the Tarot, by A.E. Waite, ill. by Pamela Colman Smith [1911], at sacred-texts.com The face suggests that of a dark woman, whose qualities might be summed up in the idea of greatness of soul; she has also the serious cast of intelligence; she contemplates her symbol and may see worlds therein. Arthur experiences the Wheel of Fortune as a vision in a dream. Because whether we see it as the halfway point of the Major Arcana, or simply one of the steps to completing the second line, the Wheel is indeed a vision given to us by the unconscious. The Hermit has turned away from the outer world. As a result the unconscious shows him a vision of life as a turning wheel filled with symbols.

We come then to the truth that both the random events of life and the so-called ‘laws’ of the physical universe are mysteries leading us to an awareness of the spirit force drawn down by the upraised arm of the Magician and manifested in the natural world of the Empress. A great many mystics and shamans have said that their visions showed them how all things connect, how everything fits together, because the spirit unites the entire universe. Possibly we would all see and understand this grand scheme of life, if it were not for the fact that we do not live long enough. Our short lives narrow our vision to such a miniscule portion of the world that life appears meaningless. Now, this idea of the Wheel as the mystery of fate, with its hidden meaning, fits very well the modern Waite-Smith version of the card, especially when we consider it as halfway to the final trump. If we place the Rider pack Wheel beside the World we see immediately the link between them. In one we have a wheel filled with symbols; in the other we find a wreath of victory, and inside it a dancer who embodies the truth behind the symbols. Even more striking, we find the same four animals on each card in the corners, except that the mythological beings of card 10 have been transformed into something real and alive in the World. Thus, at the halfway point, we receive a vision of the inner meaning of life; at the end that vision has become real, embodied in our own being.

explanations such as ‘best possible outcome’ for the positions. Following Crowley and others, several contemporary books have attempted to widen the meaning of the cards by linking them not only to astrology and the Qabalah but to the 1 Ching, Jungian psychology, Tantra, even Central American mythology. Such linking aids understanding, particularly for those people with a previous knowledge of the other system (it would be interesting to see a book about, say, gestalt psy¬ chology which explains its subject in terms of Tarot correspondence rather than the other way round). Still, the emphasis for any careful study of Tarot must remain with the cards themselves, and with their use in meditation and in readings. This section of the book hopes to give at least a sense of just how complex and deeply instructive a tool Tarot divination can be. Many people say that Tarot readings ‘scare’ them. What they mean by this is first a discomfort that anything should expose their experiences, as well as their inner fears and their hopes; and second, that a pack of cards should do so. They may approach the Tarot first as a game, especially if a friend or relative lays the cards so that they do not have to pay for the reading. They mix the cards, grinning a little, for they feel foolish; the reader lays them out, perhaps looking up the meanings in a book, and amazingly, out comes the new job, or the unfaithful lover or, if the reader approaches it a little more subtly, perhaps the fear of illness or a painful rebellion against a parent. ‘You’re making that up from what you know about me,’ they say, or ‘You could tell all that from looking at me, couldn’t you? You didn’t really get that from the cards.'

Now, the cover card usually stands for some basic influence on the subject, a general situation or starting point for the reading. The second card, which we always read right side up, despite how it comes off the deck, represents in traditional systems an ‘opposing influence’, something counter to the first. In practice, this ‘opposition’ may actually form a second influence supporting the first. For example, suppose the cover card was the Fool, indicat¬ ing a sense of following instincts despite what may seem the more sensible practice. If Temperance crossed it, we could call it an opposition, since Temperance usually refers to caution. But if the Knight of Wands crossed the Fool, the two cards would tend to support each other, and in fact the other cards might suggest a need for a more temperate influence to balance all that eagerness. In my work I have developed a slightly different way of looking at the first two cards, referring to them not as cover and ‘opposition’ but as ‘Centre’ and ‘crossing’. For their meanings I term them the ‘inner’ and ‘outer’ aspects, or some¬ times ‘vertical’ and ‘horizontal’ time, or simply ‘being’ and ‘doing’. The Centre card shows some basic quality of the person or the person’s situation. I'he crossing card then shows how that quality affects the person, or how it translates into action. Put another way, the first shows what the person is, the second how he or she acts. Consider the example in Fig. 57. The Fool would indicate a person with an inner tendency to take chances, to follow instinct. Temperance crossing it would mean that when it comes to action the person tends towards a more careful approach, blending instinctive energy with more practical considerations.

In Part One of this book I wrote that readings partake of both the Magician and the High Priestess principles, con¬ sciousness and intuition. We can go further and say that doing Tarot readings helps achieve a balance and unity of these principles in their practical states, that of will and openness. Each time we do a reading we assert our will to impose a meaning on the patterns thrown out by chaos. The act suggests not only the Magician (number 1) but the Wheel of Fortune (number 10). The latter card carries a vision of the world in time (remember the Wirth version of the Wheel as resting in a boat - consciousness - floating on the sea of existence). However, meaning imposed by consciousness carries true value only if we open ourselves to the pictures and the impact they make on us. Therefore, Tarot readings suggest the High Priestess (number 2), but also the Hanged Man (number 12), the image of such a close connection to life that we no longer see ourselves as separate or opposed to it. And the card that connects trumps 10 and 12 can also stand for the emblem of Tarot readings themselves: Justice, her scales forever balanced not by a careful weighing of opposites - so much intuition for so much objective knowledge - but by a living commitment to the truth. Chinese people Pentacles, most Swedes Wands, and so on. A more objective system uses astrological signs. As described earlier, the four elements signify signs of the zodiac, as well as the suits of Tarot. Most people know their own sun signs and if not the reader can readily determine it from the birthday. Of course, most astrologers say that the sun sign constitutes only one twelfth of the person’s chart

If any device will provide meaning, why Tarot? The answer is, any system will tell us something, but the quality of that something depends on the values contained in the system. The Tarot contains a philosophy, an outline of how human con¬ sciousness evolves, and a vast compendium of human experience. Shuffling the cards brings all these values into play with each other. We might argue that assigning a philosophy to the cards destroys their objectivity in terms of predicting events. Human values and interpretations have intruded in an otherwise.pure system. Such an idea, I think, would come from a misunder¬ standing of ‘objectivity’. The Tarot is objective because it bypasses conscious decision, but it is not impartial. On the contrary, it attempts to push us in certain directions: optimism, spirituality, a belief in the necessity and value of change. The meanings for the cards given in this book leave a good deal of room for interpretation by the reader. In fact, they require it. This is because the practised reader brings far more to her or his work than a detailed knowledge of the cards and their traditional meanings. Just as important is sensitivity - both to the pictures and to the person sitting there nervously and excitedly staring at the cards. A good reader does not simply repeat traditional fixed meanings. Rather, he or she will find new meanings and interpretations, will extend the patterns. While some people desire objective readings and dislike interpretation, others argue that a reader should not use any definite meanings at all, but always work from ‘feeling' the pictures at the moment. Yet to do so will limit the reader to the narrow range of his or her own perceptions. And those perceptions will always come at least partly from his or her

### Step 1: 整体氛围分析（宏观分析）

**大阿卡纳/小阿卡纳比例分析**  
在这次牌阵中，大阿卡纳牌的数量适中（2张），分别是逆位的命运之轮和塔牌。这表明这次解读涉及到一些重要的人生课题，但整体上仍然偏重于日常生活中的具体事务。

**元素分布分析**  
权杖（3张）和宝剑（3张）占据了主导地位，显示出这次解读的驱动力是行动和思考。这可能指示着一种需要积极行动和理智思考的状态。圣杯和星币元素各有一张，表明在情感和物质方面的作用较弱，值得注意的是，情感和物质领域可能需要更多的关注和平衡。

**数字能量分析**  
数字6和7重复出现，指示出当前事件处于从稳定到挑战的过渡阶段。数字序列6到7再到8，预示着逐步的进展和即将到来的突破。

### Step 2: 核心意象整合（直觉整合）

在这场财务旅程中，逆位的命运之轮暗示着机会的错失和不稳定的循环，与此相交的是圣杯王牌，象征着潜在的情感满足和财富机会。金币骑士的出现，提示着稳重的积累策略，但缺乏灵活性。过去的剑王象征着智慧和权威，而即将到来的六根权杖代表着短暂的胜利。塔牌提醒着自我的觉醒与重建，周围环境的六把剑则带来过渡的平静。逆位的七根权杖表明内心的斗争，最终八根权杖预示着迅速的进展。

### Step 3: 叙述构建（叙述构建）

在过去，你的朋友可能依赖于智慧（剑王），以理性和逻辑驾驭生活。然而，命运之轮的逆位显示出尽管有智慧的指导，生活中仍然有无法掌控的变数和停滞。圣杯王牌的出现提示着内心深处有寻求情感满足的渴望，但可能因为环境或内心的混乱而错过机会。

随着时间的推移，虽然在某些方面取得了胜利（六根权杖），但塔牌的出现代表着突如其来的转变，迫使重新评估和调整策略。周围环境中的六把剑则带来了从混乱到平静的过渡，可能通过更好的沟通和自我反省实现。

内心的斗争（逆位的七根权杖）可能反映了对未知的恐惧或失去控制的担忧。然而，最终的结果（八根权杖）表明，只要果断行动，事情将会迅速进展，带来意想不到的突破。

### Step 4: 提炼关键见解（关键见解）

1. **变革与适应**：生活中的不确定性和变革是不可避免的，关键在于如何灵活应对和适应。
2. **情感与理智的平衡**：在追求物质和情感满足时，需要理智的判断和情感的平衡。
3. **行动的力量**：果断的行动和清晰的目标将带来积极的进展和突破。

### Step 5: 提供建设性的可操作指导（可操作指导）

**积极指导**  
尽管存在挑战，通过适应变化和平衡情感与理智，可以实现个人成长和转型。

**具体建议**  
1. **加强沟通与反省**：利用周围的支持系统，通过有效的沟通和反省，逐步走出困境。
2. **制定明确的行动计划**：根据当前的情况，制定清晰的目标和计划，勇敢地迈出行动的步伐。

**强调个人力量**  
请记住，这次解读揭示的是当前的能量趋势和可能性，而最终的选择权在你朋友的手中，他可以通过自己的努力和决定来塑造未来。

steps.prompt_content:
# Role Setting

You are an experienced and insightful Tarot reader. Your interpretation style is not simply to repeat card meanings, but to weave the card imagery, the question, and intuitive impressions into a complete, coherent, and guiding narrative. Please maintain an objective, neutral, and empathetic tone.

# Reading Background Information

## User Question:
算一下我朋友的人生走势，什么时候发财，什么时候结婚，难度是high

## Question Analysis:
- Domain: finance
- Question Type: specific_event

## Spread and Cards:
1. cover: Wheel of Fortune [Reversed]
2. crossing: Ace of Cups
3. basis: Knight of Pentacles
4. behind: King of Swords
5. crowned: Seven of Swords
6. before: Six of Wands
7. self: The Tower
8. environment: Six of Swords
9. hopes_and_fears: Seven of Wands [Reversed]
10. outcome: Eight of Wands

## Core Intuitive Imagery:
在这场充满象征意味的财务之旅中，逆位的命运之轮在阴影中缓缓转动，仿佛命运的齿轮有些许停滞，暗示着机会的错失或停滞不前。与之交织的是圣杯王牌的溢满之水，象征着潜在的收益和情感的满足，然而也提醒着人们，在追求财富时，要小心不被情感所迷惑。基础位置的金币骑士则如同一位守财的工匠，专注于眼前的任务，稳定却缺乏变通，隐喻着脚踏实地的积累和耐心的投资策略。

在这静谧的画面中，剑王的智慧和权威成为了过去的基石，他如同一位睿智的统治者，以敏锐的判断力扫视全局。而在前方，六根权杖高举胜利的旗帜，象征着短暂的成功和战斗后的荣耀，然而这只是旅途的一部分。自我的塔牌则如雷霆般撕裂天空，带来突如其来的觉醒和重新评估现状的机会，揭示出在财务领域中，变革和意外是不可避免的。

周围环境中的六把剑则如渡河般带来了平静的过渡，暗示着通过沟通和反思，逐步走向更明朗的未来。希望与恐惧中逆位的七根权杖则提醒着潜在的内心斗争，或许是对失去控制的担忧。而结局位置的八根权杖如同流星般快速划过夜空，象征着迅速的进展和事态的发展，预示着在财务方面，果断和行动将带来最终的突破和完成。整个画面交织着变革与稳定、内省与行动，勾勒出一幅充满动感且富有深意的财务旅程。
(This imagery is the intuitive core of this reading. Please be sure to use it as the main thread and source of inspiration for the interpretation.)

## Pattern Analysis Results (Macro Energy Scan):

# Interpretation Task Instructions

Please strictly follow these five steps to provide a complete and in-depth Tarot reading:

**Step 1: Overall Atmosphere Analysis (Macro Analysis)**
Before delving into individual cards, please conduct a macro "energy scan" of the entire spread based on the [Pattern Analysis Results] and briefly explain its meaning:
- **Major/Minor Arcana Ratio Analysis**: Based on `major_arcana_patterns`, analyze whether the fundamental level of the question leans towards "significant life lessons" (Major Arcana dominant) or "specific matters of daily life" (Minor Arcana dominant).
- **Elemental Distribution Analysis**: Based on `suit_distribution`, identify the most prominent elemental energies (the driving forces) and any missing elements (areas needing attention).
- **Numeric Energy Analysis**: Based on `number_patterns`, determine which stage of development the current event is in (e.g., beginning, conflict, stability, completion).

**Step 2: Core Imagery Integration (Intuitive Integration)**
This is the heart of the interpretation. Please deeply integrate the [Core Intuitive Imagery] as a central thread running through the entire reading. Analyze how this imagery resonates with the symbolic meaning of each card and use it to connect the relationships between the cards.

**Step 3: Narrative Construction (Narrative Construction)**
Now, weave all the information into a smooth, logical story. Please unfold the narrative according to the spread's sequence (e.g., Past-Present-Future), explaining how one card develops into the next to reveal the underlying causal logic.

**Step 4: Distill Key Insights (Key Insights)**
Based on the narrative, clearly summarize 1-3 of the most critical key insights or fundamental issues revealed by this reading regarding the question asked.

**Step 5: Provide Constructive Actionable Guidance (Actionable Guidance)**
Finally, based on all the analysis above, provide specific, positive, and actionable advice.
- **Positive Guidance**: Even if the cards show challenges, find the lessons for growth and the potential for transformation.
- **Specific Recommendations**: Based on the energy analysis from Step 1 (e.g., missing elements) and the key insights from Step 4, offer 1-2 concrete action steps.
- **Emphasize Personal Power**: Conclude by reiterating that the cards reveal current energy trends and possibilities, but the querent holds the ultimate power of choice to shape their future.

# Important Notes
- **Critical Thinking**: The [RAG Retrieved Information] may contain repetitive, contradictory, or not entirely accurate content. Please act as an expert, critically screening, integrating, and refining the information to form a logically coherent and insightful interpretation.
- **Output Language**: Please generate your complete interpretation in **Chinese**, using Markdown format for the best readability.
- **Accessibility and Clarity**: This interpretation will be read by people who may have little or no knowledge of Tarot divination. Please minimize the use of technical jargon and specialized terminology. When you must use Tarot-specific terms (such as "Major Arcana", "reversed", "suit", etc.), provide clear explanations or context so that non-experts can understand. Offer detailed and comprehensive explanations throughout your interpretation, ensuring that every concept, symbol, and insight is thoroughly explained in accessible language. Your goal is to make the reading meaningful and understandable to someone encountering Tarot for the first time.
